challenges: Limited access to accurate, timely and spatially explicit information on the state of marine and coastal environments in West and North Africa.
Increasing pressure on marine and coastal resources due to population growth, urbanisation, industrialisation, and climate change impacts.
Inadequate local capacity, infrastructure and coordination mechanisms to generate, disseminate and use Earth Observation-based marine and coastal information services.
Fragmented data and knowledge across institutions and countries, limiting effective regional marine and coastal governance.
Need to support regional and national efforts to achieve sustainable development goals related to oceans, coasts and climate resilience.
focus: Development and provision of Earth Observation-based marine and coastal information services to support sustainable management of marine and coastal resources in North and West Africa.
Strengthening institutional, human and technical capacities for operational marine and coastal EO services.
Supporting implementation of policies and strategies related to marine and coastal management, climate change and blue economy at regional and national levels.
Enhancing data sharing, knowledge exchange and collaboration among marine and coastal institutions in West and North Africa.
rationale: Marine and coastal areas in North and West Africa are critical for food security, livelihoods, trade, biodiversity and climate regulation.
These areas face significant threats from overexploitation, pollution, habitat degradation and climate change impacts such as sea level rise and coastal erosion.
Earth Observation provides a powerful tool to monitor, assess and manage marine and coastal environments over large areas and time scales.
The MarCNoWA project aims to build on the achievements of GMES & Africa Phase 1 to deliver operational, user-driven marine and coastal EO services.
The project will contribute to regional and continental priorities related to sustainable blue economy, climate resilience and environmental governance.

challenges: Need to monitor water resources and their evolution for river navigation.
Need to monitor the hydrological balance of sub-basins of major rivers in the Congo basin and connected basins.
Need to monitor hydrological behavior of wetlands and flooded forest areas in the central African region.
Limited technical and institutional capacities to fully use satellite-based Earth Observation for integrated water resource management.
Need to strengthen regional cooperation and data sharing between countries that share transboundary water resources.
focus: Development of operational EO-based services for monitoring water levels, river navigation conditions, and hydrological balance in the Congo-Oubangui-Sangha basin and connected basins.
Monitoring of wetlands and flooded forest dynamics in the central African region using satellite data.
Capacity building of regional and national institutions in the use of EO data and tools for water resource management.
Support to decision-making for integrated water resource management and climate resilience.
Awareness raising and training of stakeholders on the benefits of EO for water and natural resource management.
rationale: The Congo-Oubangui-Sangha basin and connected basins play a critical role in regional hydrology, ecosystems, and livelihoods in Central Africa.
River navigation, fisheries, agriculture, and ecosystems depend on the availability and dynamics of surface water and wetlands.
Climate change and human activities are affecting hydrological regimes, increasing the need for better monitoring and management.
Earth Observation offers unique capabilities to monitor large and often inaccessible areas on a regular basis.

The project aims to provide decision-makers with reliable, spatially explicit information on water resources, navigation conditions, and wetlands to support sustainable management and adaptation to climate change.

challenges: Environmental risks/threats and illegal behaviour (i.e., IUU fishing and other maritime crimes) pose major risks to marine resources, coastal ecosystems and livelihoods in the region.
Limited in-situ observations and sparse monitoring infrastructure make it difficult to obtain accurate, near-real-time data for effective monitoring and enforcement.
Small-scale fishers and coastal communities often lack access to trusted, localized information and tools that can support sustainable fishing and safer operations at sea.
Coastal ecosystems, including coral reefs, seagrass beds and mangroves, are under pressure from climate change, pollution and unsustainable use and need improved monitoring.
Operational sea rescue and maritime safety services require better integrated information on sea state, vessel activity and risk conditions.
focus: Development and provision of EO-based services for ship traffic monitoring, surveillance and maritime situational awareness.
Design and implementation of sea rescue applications that support decision-making and incident response.
Support to aquaculture and fisheries decision-making, with a strong emphasis on community empowerment and co-designed information services.
Operational monitoring of coastal ecosystems and water quality, including coral bleaching risk and impacts.
Integration of satellite data, in-situ observations and user knowledge into decision-support tools for a wide range of marine and coastal stakeholders.
rationale: Southern Africa and the Western Indian Ocean are home to highly productive fisheries, rich marine biodiversity and critical maritime transport routes.
Climate change, overfishing, pollution and illegal activities are increasingly threatening marine ecosystems, food security and coastal livelihoods.
Earth Observation can provide frequent, synoptic and objective information on ocean conditions, ship traffic, coastal ecosystems and extreme events.
There is a need to translate EO data into user-friendly applications, mobile tools and dashboards that can be used by decision-makers, operational agencies and communities.
The MarCOSIO project builds on regional partnerships to deliver operational, user-driven marine and coastal EO services for Southern Africa and the Indian Ocean region.
